page.name: Full Stack Development
page.description: Full Stack Development is the end-to-end development of web applications, where a developer handles the client-side (front-end), server-side (back-end), APIs, databases, and deployment infrastructure. A full stack developer is capable of building an entire functional product from UI to server logic and managing deployment.

section.name: Introduction
content: Everything that the user sees and interacts with in their browser or app. It’s about the look & feel and user experience (UX) of an application. Examples: Webpages: buttons, menus, forms, animations. Mobile app screens. Styling, colors, layouts.

2. The frontend is what the user sees and interacts with — so it needs to be: Beautiful and consistent Fast and responsive Easy to use on all devices (mobile, tablet, desktop) Accessible to everyone. To build such high-quality interfaces efficiently, you need the right skills and use modern tools that save time and improve quality.

3. The part of the application that runs on the server and handles: Business logic, Database operations, Authentication & authorization, Serving data to the frontend. Users don’t see the backend — it powers the app behind the scenes. Examples: Storing user data. Validating login credentials. Processing payments.

4. The backend is essential because it: Stores, processes, and protects data. Handles business logic. Manages user authentication & security. Connects the frontend to the database and other services. Ensures scalability, reliability, and performance of the application. Without a backend, its functions cannot simply be replaced by any code.

section.name: Application Server
content: 1. An application server is software (and often also the hardware it runs on) that provides an environment to run and manage applications, especially web or enterprise applications. It sits between the web server (which handles HTTP requests/responses) and the database server (where data is stored).

2. The application server contains the business logic of your application. It processes data, applies rules, connects to databases, and sends back the result (usually via a web server) to the client/browser.

3. Features of application servers: Provide APIs for building applications; manage application components (like servlets, EJBs in Java EE); handle transactions, security, and resource pooling; support scalability and load balancing.

4. Example: When you visit an e-commerce website — the web server handles your HTTP request and forwards it. The application server processes your login, shopping cart, or payment using its application logic. It fetches or updates data in the database and sends the response back.

section.name: Html, Css and Javascript
section.svg: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><svg version="1.1" id="Layer_1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" x="0px" y="0px" width="21" viewBox="0 0 108.35 122.88" style="enable-background:new 0 0 108.35 122.88" xml:space="preserve"><style>.st0{fill-rule:evenodd;clip-rule:evenodd;}.st1{fill-rule:evenodd;clip-rule:evenodd;fill:#f16529;}.st2{fill-rule:evenodd;clip-rule:evenodd;fill:#ebebeb;}.st3{fill-rule:evenodd;clip-rule:evenodd;fill:#ffffff;}</style><g><polygon class="st1" points="108.35,0 98.48,110.58 54.11,122.88 9.86,110.6 0,0 108.35,0"/><polygon class="st0" points="54.17,113.48 90.03,103.54 98.46,9.04 54.17,9.04 54.17,113.48"/><path class="st2" d="M34.99,36.17h19.19V22.61H20.16l0.32,3.64l3.33,37.38h30.35V50.06H36.23L34.99,36.17z M38.04,70.41H24.43l1.9,21.3 l27.79,7.71V85.29l-15.11-4.08L38.04,70.41z"/><path class="st3" d="M54.13,63.63h16.7l-1.57,17.59L54.13,85.3v14.11l27.81-7.71l3.39-38.35H54.13V63.63z M54.13,36.14h32.76 l1.21-13.57H54.13V36.14z"/></g></svg>
content: 1. These three work together to create web pages.

2. HTML (HyperText Markup Language): The structure of a web page. Defines the content and layout of a page. Tells the browser what each part of the page is (headings, paragraphs, images, links, forms, etc.). Think of HTML as the skeleton of the page.

3. CSS (Cascading Style Sheets): The style and design of the page. Makes the page look nice — colors, fonts, layouts, animations. Separates content (HTML) from design. Think of CSS as the clothing and makeup of the page.

4. JavaScript: The behavior and interactivity of the page. Adds logic and functionality to web pages. Can update content without reloading the page (dynamic). Think of JavaScript as the brain of the page.
